guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

body:
> It's not Jewish or rabbinic theology, it's pure, clear-cut Hebrew Bible exegesis, and I'm not relying on it, I was offering some guidance.

It was a jewish rabbi. A rabbinical interpretation is not the most clear cut thing, it's an interpretation influenced by a religious tradition. It's actually rather difficult to come up with a factual exegesis since the culture and language dialect is so ancient.

> Why would I do that, what would be the point, and what would be so horrible if you looked like an "anti-semite"? You just seem very confused, maybe because you try to extrapolate and fabricate narratives that aren't there. Life is is easier when you don't do that.

Re-reading the conversation I'm not as sure now. But it does seem like you tried to lure people into arguing over whether you're Jewish or not, which can then easily be misconstrued as them thinking bad=Jewish.
body_html:
It's not Jewish or rabbinic theology, it's pure, clear-cut Hebrew Bible exegesis, and I'm not relying on it, I was offering some guidance.

It was a jewish rabbi. A rabbinical interpretation is not the most clear cut thing, it's an interpretation influenced by a religious tradition. It's actually rather difficult to come up with a factual exegesis since the culture and language dialect is so ancient.

Why would I do that, what would be the point, and what would be so horrible if you looked like an "anti-semite"? You just seem very confused, maybe because you try to extrapolate and fabricate narratives that aren't there. Life is is easier when you don't do that.

Re-reading the conversation I'm not as sure now. But it does seem like you tried to lure people into arguing over whether you're Jewish or not, which can then easily be misconstrued as them thinking bad=Jewish.

body:
That's good to hear, and it means that your mindset is the opposite of the vast vast majority of Christians (despite what they might think of themselves). I don't know if you're a trinitarian, comes from the Christian tradition or what's you background and present path, but the first step should be purging yourself of Christians lies and idols:

https://m.youtube.com/user/TheTrinityDelusion

This man, brother Kel, does an excellent job conclusively shattering the ridicolous lie of the trinity abomination from a scriptural perspective. And just to clarify, the trinity abomination is not and never was fully deducted from scripture, nor what it ever intended to. However, certain branches of Evangelical and Americanized Christianity follows a perverted idea where they think they reject tradition (because they're as ignorant as they as dishonest) and follow "the Bible" alone (which is also a complete bastardization of Luther's original concept of sola scriptura). And Evangelicals don't even know what they worship anyway, or basic trinitarian theology. 

Anyway, if you want to learn the conception of the trinity abomination and the foundation and idol that came to define Christianity you need to look up: The First Council of Nicea 325 AD (convoked by emperor Constantine, marking the beginning of state sponsored ecumenism), the First Council of Constantinople 381 AD, and the Edict of Thessalonica 380 AD. The key is the Edict of Thessalonica 380 AD, an imperial, secular edict, co-authored by emperor Theodosius, that made the Nicene orthodoxy of Rome and Alexandria mandatory state religion, before he convoked the mock council that followed. Not unlike the Mark of the Beast Christians are still waiting for. 

Anyway, if you really want to open a can of worms in search of truth, look up Tovia Singer and other anti-missionary Jews, and learn what their actual objections are, and how Christianity and the Church has perverted, mistranslated and twisted the Hebrew Bible throughout the ages. And no, it's not because they were expecting a military messiah and Jesus was too peaceful, that's just another Christian lie. And although Tovia Singer is an Orthodox Jewish Rabbi, his anti-missionary apologetics is based on the Hebrew Bible alone, not Talmud. Which brings me to my next point.

Orthodox Jews (the literal descendents of Pharisees and Pharisaism), as you might know, believe in something called the "Oral" (ironically written down) Torah or Talmud. This they claim, was given to Moses alongside the biblical Torah to be orally traded between the generations (which is also an obviously ridicolous claim on so many levels since it contains contradictory rulings from later Rabbinical schools of thought). 

Anyway, when Jesus according to the canonical gospels was talking about the teachings and traditions of the Pharisees, that was what he meant, not that they were following the Torah *too well* or that they were *too legalistic*, as Christians would have you believe. Which brings me to my next point; Karaite Judaism. Karaites reject the authority of the Rabbinate and the Oral Torah. A name you should look up to understand Karaism is Nehemia Gordon. 

And you should also do some research on Paul the false apostle and fake Pharisee, and why he in all likelihood wasn't even a Jew (search Paul + charlatan + Tovia Singer on YT to get started, but you could also Google Paul + false apostle and I'm sure you'll find some interesting information). 

Do your research, familiarize yourself with basic Christian history, pray, pray, pray, and make sure you pay attention to your dreams. 

And may God guide your soul accordingly.

And may God guide your soul accordingly.

body:
I appreciate your time to write out a well explained jumping off point. I grew up american christian. Turned my back, but began asking the big questions in life. It was actually astronomy, physics, and science that ultimately proved fruitless to me and led me directly back to god.

Do i i have my faith in Jesus? Yes. I am also still a child at heart-my earthly intelligence and success only attributed to consistantly asking "why?".  My first priority will always be my relationship with god. The word is then my guide in that relationship, but i continue to seek the deeper meaning and historical accuracy. I will take this as a challenge to learn and grow, and as you say, let prayer be a guide.

May be a stupid question, but do you then consider yourself Unitarian? Thanks again for your time and expanding on your beliefs. God bless, and we all certainly need it.

Lastly, any reliable books? The internet truth can certainly turn into an endless rabbit hole.

I've spent a lot of time researching. Plenty of brother Kel and Tovia. And the very same night of this discussion i had a dream. Part of it that was unrelated was a loud and clear message. The other part involved three speakers at a wedding, but still struggling with interpretation.  Very significant as the details are still very clear which is rare in my experience.

Out of curiosity, where did all of this lead you personally? If what you believe can be placed under a general umbrella. 
 This discussion certainly broadened my horizons, which is always a good thing.

parent.body:
That's good to hear, and it means that your mindset is the opposite of the vast vast majority of Christians (despite what they might think of themselves). I don't know if you're a trinitarian, comes from the Christian tradition or what's you background and present path, but the first step should be purging yourself of Christians lies and idols:

https://m.youtube.com/user/TheTrinityDelusion

This man, brother Kel, does an excellent job conclusively shattering the ridicolous lie of the trinity abomination from a scriptural perspective. And just to clarify, the trinity abomination is not and never was fully deducted from scripture, nor what it ever intended to. However, certain branches of Evangelical and Americanized Christianity follows a perverted idea where they think they reject tradition (because they're as ignorant as they as dishonest) and follow "the Bible" alone (which is also a complete bastardization of Luther's original concept of sola scriptura). And Evangelicals don't even know what they worship anyway, or basic trinitarian theology. 

Anyway, if you want to learn the conception of the trinity abomination and the foundation and idol that came to define Christianity you need to look up: The First Council of Nicea 325 AD (convoked by emperor Constantine, marking the beginning of state sponsored ecumenism), the First Council of Constantinople 381 AD, and the Edict of Thessalonica 380 AD. The key is the Edict of Thessalonica 380 AD, an imperial, secular edict, co-authored by emperor Theodosius, that made the Nicene orthodoxy of Rome and Alexandria mandatory state religion, before he convoked the mock council that followed. Not unlike the Mark of the Beast Christians are still waiting for. 

Anyway, if you really want to open a can of worms in search of truth, look up Tovia Singer and other anti-missionary Jews, and learn what their actual objections are, and how Christianity and the Church has perverted, mistranslated and twisted the Hebrew Bible throughout the ages. And no, it's not because they were expecting a military messiah and Jesus was too peaceful, that's just another Christian lie. And although Tovia Singer is an Orthodox Jewish Rabbi, his anti-missionary apologetics is based on the Hebrew Bible alone, not Talmud. Which brings me to my next point.

Orthodox Jews (the literal descendents of Pharisees and Pharisaism), as you might know, believe in something called the "Oral" (ironically written down) Torah or Talmud. This they claim, was given to Moses alongside the biblical Torah to be orally traded between the generations (which is also an obviously ridicolous claim on so many levels since it contains contradictory rulings from later Rabbinical schools of thought). 

Anyway, when Jesus according to the canonical gospels was talking about the teachings and traditions of the Pharisees, that was what he meant, not that they were following the Torah *too well* or that they were *too legalistic*, as Christians would have you believe. Which brings me to my next point; Karaite Judaism. Karaites reject the authority of the Rabbinate and the Oral Torah. A name you should look up to understand Karaism is Nehemia Gordon. 

And you should also do some research on Paul the false apostle and fake Pharisee, and why he in all likelihood wasn't even a Jew (search Paul + charlatan + Tovia Singer on YT to get started, but you could also Google Paul + false apostle and I'm sure you'll find some interesting information). 

Do your research, familiarize yourself with basic Christian history, pray, pray, pray, and make sure you pay attention to your dreams. 

And may God guide your soul accordingly.

body:
>May be a stupid question, but do you then consider yourself Unitarian? 

Hey, sorry for the really late reply. I wanted to give you the effort reply you and this subject deserve, but I struggled to find the mental energy. No, I don't use the word "unitarian". Unitarian is a ridicolous word that only exist (deceitfully) in relation to the word trinitarian, as were they two interpretations of monotheism (trinitarianism is polytheism). I'm a monotheist. 

>Lastly, any reliable books? The internet truth can certainly turn into an endless rabbit hole.

Tovia Singer has two volumes called Let's Get Biblical 1 and 2, but as I'm sure you've already learned, you can get a very foundational understanding from the material found online.  Bart Ehrman is another scholar and author if you want to study the reliability and history of canonicity and Christian scripture. He also has a blog and a lot of videos on YT. James Tabor is another author I've been meaning to check out, his focus is on the original Judaic/Abrahamic roots of Christianity. 

But like I said, so much information is already available at tip of your fingers. Especially when it comes to documented Christian history. The writings of the ante-Nicene church fathers, the ecumenical councils, the schisms, etc. But I'll elaborate more on this in a later post. 

And regarding the truth and various internet rabbit holes. This is the amazing thing; if you are a truthful person, you will be able to tell truth from lies with no problem what so ever. The more you learn, the more truth will becomes self-evident and, more importantly, demonstrable. 

As you've surely already learned, when Tovia Singer makes a statement or answers a question objection -- say the subject is a *willful* mistranslation in the Christian Bible -- he will explicitly reiterate over and over and over not to trust his word on it, but to look it up for yourself. He will provide you with the tools and examples for you to make your own decisions. And someone like Ehrman, he's a scholar; he doesn't make empty statements without proper references and certain academic rigour (not to says academia can't be corrupt, but you get my point), he's not presenting his personal opinion, nor is his personal opinion relevant. 

That is how truth works, and that's the difference between those dwelling in truth and light and the snithering snakes of the lie that want you to "trust them", that can't stop contradicting themselves, and that can't stop with the special pleading. There's a reason soohists like Ravi Zacharias and William Lane Craig can become apologetic superstars in (Evangelical) Christianity. 

Bit you'll notice that for yourself too, and I'll elaborate more on this later too, and reply to your other comment.

parent.body:
I appreciate your time to write out a well explained jumping off point. I grew up american christian. Turned my back, but began asking the big questions in life. It was actually astronomy, physics, and science that ultimately proved fruitless to me and led me directly back to god.

Do i i have my faith in Jesus? Yes. I am also still a child at heart-my earthly intelligence and success only attributed to consistantly asking "why?".  My first priority will always be my relationship with god. The word is then my guide in that relationship, but i continue to seek the deeper meaning and historical accuracy. I will take this as a challenge to learn and grow, and as you say, let prayer be a guide.

May be a stupid question, but do you then consider yourself Unitarian? Thanks again for your time and expanding on your beliefs. God bless, and we all certainly need it.

Lastly, any reliable books? The internet truth can certainly turn into an endless rabbit hole.

>The other part involved three speakers at a wedding, but still struggling with interpretation.

That's amazing to hear. "Biblically" speaking a wedding represent the covenant between God and God's People/the children of Israel/a church/congregation of believers (the bride). If the bride is, say, a whore of unfaithful that represents idolatry. Of course, in this context I would be tempted to say the speakers represent the trinity abomination, but I've encountered these figures of three before, and I'll refrain from interpretating it. You didn't hear what the speakers were saying at all? 

Another important symbol you should keep in mind for yourself is that clothes of garments represent sin. In can also be symbolized as blemished or wounds on your skin. 

>Out of curiosity, where did all of this lead you personally?

It lead me to God's law, and the realization that Christianity is the one pre-eminent satanic manifestation on this planet. That might be a hard pill to swallow for those coming from Christian roots, but it's the truth nonetheless. You said your background was American Christianity. Would that be Evangelicalism?

parent.body:
I've spent a lot of time researching. Plenty of brother Kel and Tovia. And the very same night of this discussion i had a dream. Part of it that was unrelated was a loud and clear message. The other part involved three speakers at a wedding, but still struggling with interpretation.  Very significant as the details are still very clear which is rare in my experience.

Out of curiosity, where did all of this lead you personally? If what you believe can be placed under a general umbrella. 
 This discussion certainly broadened my horizons, which is always a good thing.

body:
Regarding the dream-it was what i equate to a royal affair. Ornate, giant cathedral, press, etc. My family and i were seated towards the front as special guests. I cannot remember what was specifically said, but the way it was all said was important. The bride was silent. She smiled throughout, but could not hear a word as her lips moved. She was also someone i went to school with and the only other recognizable person. The groom i could hear. I remember him being somewhat lighthearted. I believe told a joke that got a laugh.  When the minister spoke it was complete silence. Felt as thought the guests were hanging onto every word in reverance. Almost seemed to "feel" every word, yet i cannot remember specifics.

The second part had to do with a long road to breaking addiction. The temptatiom had begun to creep back in with rationalizations,  but this message was loud and clear.

I was raised non denominational protestant. Attended a few recently, but most options seem a square peg/round hole scenario to me. I crave the knowledge most don't offer, not a pat on the back or the ticking of a box as if everybody's there to pay dues. I question specific aspects, and i do have faith in jesus, but i also believe obedience is of utmost importance.  There is a God, and i try to keep that fact ever present in thought and action.

I crave the knowledge most don't offer, not a pat on the back or the ticking of a box as if everybody's there to pay dues. I question specific aspects, and i do have faith in jesus, but i also believe obedience is of utmost importance. There is a God, and i try to keep that fact ever present in thought and action.

parent.body:
>The other part involved three speakers at a wedding, but still struggling with interpretation.

That's amazing to hear. "Biblically" speaking a wedding represent the covenant between God and God's People/the children of Israel/a church/congregation of believers (the bride). If the bride is, say, a whore of unfaithful that represents idolatry. Of course, in this context I would be tempted to say the speakers represent the trinity abomination, but I've encountered these figures of three before, and I'll refrain from interpretating it. You didn't hear what the speakers were saying at all? 

Another important symbol you should keep in mind for yourself is that clothes of garments represent sin. In can also be symbolized as blemished or wounds on your skin. 

>Out of curiosity, where did all of this lead you personally?

It lead me to God's law, and the realization that Christianity is the one pre-eminent satanic manifestation on this planet. That might be a hard pill to swallow for those coming from Christian roots, but it's the truth nonetheless. You said your background was American Christianity. Would that be Evangelicalism?

body:
I usually don't have problem structuring my throughs in written text, but this subject is so massive I would need to write a ten volume books to cover it, so my posts are going to be more stream of contiousness. I hope tour fine with that and can follow my thoughts. 

>Almost seemed to "feel" every word, yet i cannot remember specifics.

Yes, that tend to be typical for these kinds of dreams. Whilsts normal dream tend to be manifestations of your subconscious, every day life and anxieties, these dreams tend to have a lucidity, heavy symbolism and a clear sense of message. Don't worry to much about the interpretation, just keep praying and do your research. 

>She was also someone i went to school with and the only other recognizable person.

Do you associate her with anything particular, or does her name have a symbolic meaning. 

>I was raised non denominational protestant.

Here's the problem with nondenominational and American (para-, as I would call it) Protestantism (besides the idolatry, polytheism and obvious filth). Americanized Christianity and Evangelicalicism tend to be a product of the revivalist movements, instead of mainline Protestantism, which is why Americanized Christianity is so detached from mainline Christianity and Christian history. That's why you have all these 19th century sects like SDA, JWs, Mormonism (not exactly Christianity, but a product of it), Southern Baptists, etc. (I think they're all 19th century). Some of these sects hold to a restorationalist theology -- the idea that mainline Christianity went astray and they are restoring it to its original. 

Anyway, in the main fold of American para-Protestantism you find these nondenominational churches, Evangelicalism in various forms, mega churches, televangelists, self-professed "born agains", Southern Baptists, etc. What these have in common is that they believe they follow ", biblical" Christianity and "the Bible" alone, and think of themselves as some kind of descendents in faith of the earliers Christian communities. 

The problem is, that's not even remotely close to Luther's original concept of sola scriptura. Sola scriptura don't mean that there's a self-existing, self-canonized book called "the Bible" that is "God's word" detached from tradition. When the Reformation started the canon hadn't even been officially closed, and Luther initially wanted to remove James, Jude, Hebrews and Revelation from the Latin Vulgate which would became the by-default Bible of Western Christianity. The Protestants also didn't want to found a new church, and acknowledged the creeds of the Nicene Church and at least four of the seven ecumenical councils. 

This is the root cause of all the confussion of American Evangelicalism. They claim "the Bible" was never compiled and canonized, never subject to tradition, the gospels were never titled and Catholics are not "real" Christians. Evangelicals and the false teachers and clown that lead them, don't know basic Christian history, basic Christian theology and most of the of course don't know a word of Greek or Hebrew (the very very few that do know only Greek). They also claim that the Bible is "inspired" because it's "inspired", it's "God's word" because it's "God's word" (it's all circular nonsense). And since they falsely claim in can't contradict itself (being "God's word") and only contains one singular narrative, they pick the narrative they prefer, and call the rest false teachers. 

Anyway, it's not just that Evangelicals claim to reject tradition, they don't period, but since they don't know anything about Christian history or theology, they keep using terminology they've inherited, without knowing where it comes from or what it means. They worship the trinity abomination based on the Nicene and Nicene-Constantinopolitan Creed alone, but claim to reject it conception and only doctrinal basis. They still use and misuse Nicene terminology like "person", "being" and "essence", but they don't know where it comes from or what it means. They use the formula "fully man and fully God" without know that's the Chalcedonian definition, adopted at the Council of Chalcedon 451 AD, based on the christology of Pope Leo I. The correct term is "truly man, truly God", but, like with everything, they don't even understand the concepts they've inherited and bastardized. 

This is the problem with American Evangelicalism. Of course, actual mainline Protestantism is secularized to the core, and a joke of its own, para-Protestantism is virtually the only living, dynamic branch of Christianity besides Cathodoxy. 

I'll elaborate more on this later hopefully.

>The second part had to do with a long road to breaking addiction. The temptatiom had begun to creep back in with rationalizations, but this message was loud and clear.

That's good. Stay on the path. I have a similar but maybe different story. Now you know, so just stay on the path.

body:
Completely understand stream of consciousness. I get the same way when discussing anything I'm invested in.  

Regarding the bride in the dream-no real association. Never were close, but spent time in church together. Like myself, know she had her share of ups, downs, and tragedy.

I'm following as close as possible otherwise.  Nothing is really unfamiliar at this point, its just still viewed through a basic understanding. I do my best, but trying to juggle multiple books, 2 babies, constant housework, etc.  By all means, i will pay attention and see where it all leads me. 

I understand why and what you do not agree with. For the most part, i am on board and have already been heading in that direction. Is there any umbrella term or belief you call home?  Much appreciated.  I can hardly return the favor of insight unless you want to discuss how to cook the perfect steak or bad jokes.

Americanized Christianity and Evangelicalicism tend to be a product of the revivalist movements, instead of mainline Protestantism, which is why Americanized Christianity is so detached from mainline Christianity and Christian history. That's why you have all these 19th century sects like SDA, JWs, Mormonism (not exactly Christianity, but a product of it), Southern Baptists, etc. (I think they're all 19th century). Some of these sects hold to a restorationalist theology -- the idea that mainline Christianity went astray and they are restoring it to its original.

Anyway, in the main fold of American para-Protestantism you find these nondenominational churches, Evangelicalism in various forms, mega churches, televangelists, self-professed "born agains", Southern Baptists, etc. What these have in common is that they believe they follow ", biblical" Christianity and "the Bible" alone, and think of themselves as some kind of descendents in faith of the earliers Christian communities.

The problem is, that's not even remotely close to Luther's original concept of sola scriptura. Sola scriptura don't mean that there's a self-existing, self-canonized book called "the Bible" that is "God's word" detached from tradition. When the Reformation started the canon hadn't even been officially closed, and Luther initially wanted to remove James, Jude, Hebrews and Revelation from the Latin Vulgate which would became the by-default Bible of Western Christianity. The Protestants also didn't want to found a new church, and acknowledged the creeds of the Nicene Church and at least four of the seven ecumenical councils.

This is the root cause of all the confussion of American Evangelicalism. They claim "the Bible" was never compiled and canonized, never subject to tradition, the gospels were never titled and Catholics are not "real" Christians. Evangelicals and the false teachers and clown that lead them, don't know basic Christian history, basic Christian theology and most of the of course don't know a word of Greek or Hebrew (the very very few that do know only Greek). They also claim that the Bible is "inspired" because it's "inspired", it's "God's word" because it's "God's word" (it's all circular nonsense). And since they falsely claim in can't contradict itself (being "God's word") and only contains one singular narrative, they pick the narrative they prefer, and call the rest false teachers.

Anyway, it's not just that Evangelicals claim to reject tradition, they don't period, but since they don't know anything about Christian history or theology, they keep using terminology they've inherited, without knowing where it comes from or what it means. They worship the trinity abomination based on the Nicene and Nicene-Constantinopolitan Creed alone, but claim to reject it conception and only doctrinal basis. They still use and misuse Nicene terminology like "person", "being" and "essence", but they don't know where it comes from or what it means. They use the formula "fully man and fully God" without know that's the Chalcedonian definition, adopted at the Council of Chalcedon 451 AD, based on the christology of Pope Leo I. The correct term is "truly man, truly God", but, like with everything, they don't even understand the concepts they've inherited and bastardized.

This is the problem with American Evangelicalism. Of course, actual mainline Protestantism is secularized to the core, and a joke of its own, para-Protestantism is virtually the only living, dynamic branch of Christianity besides Cathodoxy.

I'll elaborate more on this later hopefully.

The second part had to do with a long road to breaking addiction. The temptatiom had begun to creep back in with rationalizations, but this message was loud and clear.

That's good. Stay on the path. I have a similar but maybe different story. Now you know, so just stay on the path.
